intro: Burchardia umbellata var. typica, commonly known as the white bellflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to the eastern United States. It features showy, white, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. It is part of the Campanulaceae family, known for its ornamental and ecological value. Its flowers attract pollinators like bees and butterflies, contributing to local biodiversity.
